accessrestrict.head: Access Restrictions
accessrestrict.p: For preservation purposes, please serve microfilm (Misc. reels 1224-1246).

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Melvin E. Steadman. Collection, 1698-1927. Personal papers collection, The Library of Virginia, Richmond.

bioghist.head: Biographical Information
bioghist.p: Melvin Steadman (1932-1987) was a United Methodist minister, an amateur genealogist, and a historian of Northern Virginia. These papers from his personal collection are largely from the Northern Virginia counties in which Steadman centered his own work.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: Papers, 1698-1927, collected by Melvin Steadman of Northern Virginia. The collection is organized into three series: Local records, Organizational records, and Private papers. Included are accounts, bonds, correspondence, court records, deeds, estate papers, financial records, plats and surveys, school records, and wills. The bulk of the collection relates to Fairfax and Loudoun Counties and includes numerous 18th century documents. The Local records comprise the largest series and include Chancery Records, Circuit Court Records, Deeds, Fiduciary Records, Free Negro and Slave Records, Indentures, Overseers of the Poor, Road and Bridge Records, School Records, and Wills.

The Organizational records include receipts and accounts of Alexandria Boarding School and Leesburg Academy, as well as records relating to the Methodist Episcopal Church in Alexandria, Falls Church, Fairfax, Lovettsville, Loudoun, and Sussex County.

The Private papers contain estate accounts and inventories for the Binns, Chichester, Cooke, Davis, Ellzey, Hamilton, Hopkins, Lane, Lewis, McCabe, Mason, Oxley, Price, Scott, Sinclair, Taylor, Updike, Whaley, and Wrenn families, among others.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: This collection is arranged into the following series:

list.item: Series I: Local records
Series II: Organizational records
Series III: Private papers

scopecontent.p: This series includes accounts, agreements, bills, bonds, court records, deeds, election records, manumissions, petitions, plats and surveys, power of attorneys, receipts, reports, road records, and wills. The counties covered include: Alexandria, Arlington, Augusta, Clarke, Culpeper, Fairfax, Fauquier, Frederick, King and Queen, King George, Loudoun, Madison, Northumberland, Pittsylvania, Prince George, Prince William, Rockingham, Stafford, and Westmoreland Counties, Virginia. Also includes information from Henderson County, Kentucky; Frederick County, Maryland; and Jefferson County, West Virginia. The collection includes many 18th century records and is a great resource for genealogists and historians.

The materials were maintained in their original order and are arranged by category. Categories include Bonds, Circuit Court, County Court, Court of Chancery, Superior Court of Law and Chancery, Deeds, Electors Records, Fiduciary Records, Free Negro and Slave Records, Judgments, Justice of the Peace, Land Records, Marriage Records, Overseers of the Poor Records, Plats and Surveys, Reconstruction, Road and Bridge Records, School Records, and Wills.

Of note are the numerous deeds, especially those from the 18th century. The Deeds are organized by the Deed Book in which they were recorded and many include information on the sale of land and slaves. The County Records include information relating to cases brought before the County Courts. Some of the cases include judgments, promissory notes, summons, receipts, agreements, depositions, and correspondence.

arrangement.p: Arranged alphabetically by county name and then by record type.

scopecontent.p: The Organizational records series include accounts, bills, certificates, deeds, list of trustees, policies, and receipts. Included are papers of the Alexandria Boarding School and Leesburg Academy, as well as records relating to the Methodist Episcopal Church in Alexandria, Falls Church, Fairfax, Lovettsville, Loudoun, and Sussex County. Of note are affidavits and certificates concerning a dispute and charges against Thacker Muire. Muire was known for instigating numerous lawsuits in his neighborhood and was later expelled from the Methodist Episcopal Church in Sussex County, Virginia.
Boarding and tuition receipt of Charles B. Tebbs.
Includes bills for building of academy, deeds, Mutual Assurance Society policy, and newspaper clipping.
Legal opinion regarding church by Henry Hunter Davis (1850) and Church appointment (1890).
Copy of Deed of Dedication of Crossman Methodist Episcopal Church.

did.unittitle: Methodist Episcopal Church (Nelson Chapel, Fairfax Co.), 1882.

scopecontent.p: Affidavits and certificates concerning dispute and charges against Thacker Muire, who was later expelled from the church.
Testimony, petitions, correspondence and other papers regarding the case against Rev. Charles A. Davis. Rev. Davis was charged with attacking a fellow parishioner.
Blank form for application for prize money person out of service.
Assignment of right in a patent to William Palmer.

The Private Papers series contains accounts, agreements, correspondence, deeds, estate accounts and inventories, receipts, and wills. The bulk of the collection consists of estate accounts and inventories. Surnames mentioned include: Binns, Chichester, Cooke, Davis, Ellzey, Hamilton, Hopkins, Lane, Lewis, McCabe, Mason, Oxley, Price, Scott, Sinclair, Taylor, Updike, Whaley, and Wrenn, among others.

arrangement.p: Arranged alphabetically by peronal name, with miscellaneous materials arranged to the front.

scopecontent.p: Depositions of John and William Brown and William Price.
Correspondence to Chichester regarding the health of William Cooke and a disease in St. Francisville, Louisiana, that killed many slaves in the area.
Papers including correspondence, plats, and deeds (many from Thomas Lord Fairfax). Also includes the wills of William Cocke, John Graham, and Elizabeth Graham, and papers from case Graham vs. Graham.
Estate accounts, inventory, and correspondence of Amelia Darne and Nicholas Darne (will).
Release of bound servant by James Barnes.
Correspondence to Mrs. Dickins, Ossian Hall, from A. M. Fitzhugh.
Accounts and receipts. Also includes agreements for Duncan to teach in Cameron Parish, Loudoun Co.

Advertisement for the estate of James Fox.

Accounts, receipts, estate inventory, and will.
